body: Sorry, not following your solution. Are you referring to creating unique record keys per batch and treating them as inserts ?

Try setting hoodie.cleaner.commits.retained=1 to keep the number of versions at minimum.

Hudi has an option to filter out duplicate rows. For DeltaStreamer, use the flag "--filter-dupes --op INSERT". For Spark DataSource based writes, set the option hoodie.datasource.write.insert.drop.duplicates=true and hoodie.datasource.write.operation=insert

You would need to set the below configs for composite keys.

hoodie.datasource.write.keygenerator.class=org.apache.hudi.keygen.ComplexKeyGenerator
hoodie.datasource.write.recordkey.field=comma_seperated_list_of_primary_keys

First thanks for the great lib, that reduces complexity of our ETL pipelines massively!

Is the next release date in the near future? I'm asking because the latest release contains this existential bug that causes the library to simply not work. Currently I'm evaluating this as alternative to delta lake and reached the point of this issue pretty fast. Is it possible to release a hotfix that at new users are able to start working with this lib by following the getting started section and start to implement more complex data models?
Thanks @pratyakshsharma ! I will check second option and try to implement.

@rolandjohann Thanks for the feedback.. We are trying to bundle few more such fixes and release 0.6.0 later this month... backporting some fixes alone on 0.5.2 and doing a 0.5.3 may make sense though.. Let me bring this up with the community and see what everyone feels..
@lamber-ken can you please review this and land ?
Sounds good. Let us know if you face any more issues :)

>Also the above plan only works for the combination of AvroKafkaSource and SchemaRegistryProvider. Thoughts?

All for improving AvroKafkaSource/SR combo, since its heavily used.. but our framework needs to be improved generally..

Just a note:
We had 16 mln of records in the topic. According to the 0.5.2-inc version, Deltastreamer reads 5mln records at each iteration. First three runs were ok (so we've correctly ingested 15mln records). Last run seemed stuck (for 1.8 hours): no resources usage, no network usage etc. So i've asked to pump up some new data inside the topic and the job suddenly completed.
Does this means that to perform the computation we need at least some X data in Kafka? does this depends on how KafkaRDD are designed? 

Thank you!

Regarding the exception that you mentioned, I agree this is a problem when using Hudi in continuous mode. The metric names are always created in the same fashion and hence after the first run, it starts logging IllegalArgumentExceptions. We need to fix this. May be you could file a jira and contribute the fix back? :)

Regarding not being able to retrieve data at all, does it have anything to do with graphite retention period? Can you check if it is configured properly?

@bvaradar yes this has been a known issue for sometime, and has been discussed previously on slack as well. Glue catalog does not currently support **cascade** for **alter table** statements. We discussed this internally before, and @bschell has started looking into this issue. The most probable solution as of now seems to be to run alter command for each partition in case of glue catalog. However, he is still investigating further. I noticed there was no JIRA for this issue so I created one https://jira.apache.org/jira/browse/HUDI-874.

@garyli1019 : This is meant to be approximate. Finding record sizes using 2 write stats is less reliable for datasets whose records size per record tend to vary. Can we also factor in a heuristic using bloom filter settings in WriteConfig to determine the size overhead of bloom filter. This may not be perfect as this setting can change between writes. 

Independently, we can also track the size of additional metadata in each file in commit metadata to get the overhead .

best long term solution in my mind is to build these file stats as a separate consolidated metadata inside hudi itself, query that.. like any database statistics table.. anything else is a heuristic and we wont be sure if its necessarily better
